Judul: IDENTIFICATION OF MINE TAILINGS OF ALLUVIAL TIN USING MULTITEMPORAL ANALYSIS OF LANDSAT IMAGES IN BANGKA ISLAND, INDONESIA
Abstrak:
Unconventional and illegal mining activities in Bangka Island are a well-known problem in Indonesia's tin industry. Uncontrolled deforestation and a lack of tailing management are more damaging than beneficial to both nature and society. In this study, remote sensing methods were applied to differentiate the exploited from unexploited areas and tailings from non-tailings using multitemporal analysis of multispectral images from
Landsat which validated by high-resolution aerial photographs. This study was conducted on three different unconventional mining sites that represent northern, central, and southern Bangka. A series of indices were used, including the normalized difference vegetation index to separate bare land from non-bare land: the modified
normalized difference water index was used to identify bodies of water. Further analysis was then conducted for the bare-land areas excluding bodies of water. The application of the Spectral Angle Mapper showed a distribution of tailing areas on the surface of these bare lands. These results were validated by ground-truth data information
 to create a distribution map of tailings and remaining alluvial tin resources at each mining sites.
